title: Leaflet tells students ‘laughing and smiling’ could be signs of consent
text:
The pamplet has been pulled over complaints made by Aberdeen University students

A pamphlet saying ‘laughter’ and ‘direct eye contact’ can be non-verbal signs of sexual consent has been slammed by Aberdeen University students.

The leaflet, designed to reduce sexual assault and harrasment, is now being taken out of circulation after sparking backlash on campus.

Students pointed out how people often laugh in ‘awkward and uncomfortable’ situations while others said ‘it’s not consent’ if non-verbal.

But the Aberdeen University Consent Awareness and Sexual Education (CASE) group, who designed the leaflet, said they were on the same page.

A representative told The Tab: ‘They key word for this section of our pahmplet would be “possible”, as non-verbal signs in paricular cannot be used to determine consent and are often misunderstood.’

The student group said the non-verbal signs only indicated ‘possible’ consent

The ‘intersectional, feminist, anti-raist group run for students and by students’ warned only listening out for verbal signals is also not enough.

Advertisement

Verbal signs of consent in the publication include ‘I want to do this right now’ and ‘I’m ready’, while examples of non-verbal signs of no consent are ‘avoiding eye contact’ and ‘just lying there’.

CASE said people could say yes because they feel pressured to do so, while displaying body language showing their discomfort.

They added: ‘We believed that the overall work of our group and the inclusion of the phrase ‘Silence is not consent’ elsewhere on the pamphlet was enough to ensure that our message was unambiguous.

‘Evidently this was not the case and we regret to have made anyone think that non-verbal signs of possible consent can replace explicit verbal consent.’

it is NEWS to me that laughter would be considered a sign of consent ???? ppl often laugh in an awkward/uncomfortable situation.. @aberdeenuni do better https://t.co/2k9Srx8upj — Katie (@kaaatiereid) October 18, 2019

Aberdeen University said it had no input into the content of the leaflet

They apologised for any ‘distress and confusion’ caused and said they would work to make their future material clearer.

Aberdeen University said they had no input into the content of the leaflet, which also included information about contraception and the work of CASE.

A spokesperson for the university said: ‘We take the welfare of all our students and staff extremely serious and the university constantly revews and makes enhancement to its support services.’

‘The university hosted two sessions on sexual consent in conjunction with local group Choices Aberdeen as part of student orientation this September and we will look to enhance this nest year.

‘As part of our commitment to empowering out community and enhancing the wellbeing of our members on and off campus, we launched the Report Support service in February which provides a ‘one-stop shop’ that signposts users to all relevant support services and to report any incidents of sexual violence or harrasment.’

description: Aberdeen University Consent Awareness and Sexual Education (CASE) group faced backlash over a leaflet featuring non-verbal signs of consent.
